author: Anonymous Beaker
title: Creating a Purpose for the abstract function
question: What is a good tip in making a good purpose for your abstract fn?
instructor_answer:
I also had a tough time coming up with purposes for abstract functions when I took this course, but here's a couple of general things I try to keep in mind:
- Read over language section of edx, at the very bottom they have a list of the abstract function definitions, including their purpose. Those are great examples to start from.
- Your purpose is normally going to be really general, so using language like "apply f on x" or "if x matches predicate p" is totally fine. 
- AVOID tailoring your purpose to the specific functions you abstracted from
    i.e. in problem 1, you would avoid mentioning numbers or the > predicate in your purpose for andmap2, because even though all-positive? and all-greater? use lists of numbers and the > predicate, NOT all functions NEED that in order to use andmap2.
Best way is to just try writing a purpose, and then post it on piazza/ask a TA or Instructor for feedback on how to improve it :)
